Division.LongName: Div Of Molecular and Cellular Bioscience

Award.AbstractNarration:
Almost every process in bacteria depends on the dynamic and specific localization of large molecules within the cell. This research addresses the question: how do bacteria make sure all of these molecules are organized into their correct positions? This project will probe the molecular and biophysical basis of cellular organization, including the role of positional constraints in regulating both essential and non-essential processes. The study will be carried out by undergraduate and graduate students in a highly mentored, collaborative research environment that emphasizes learning-through-teaching experiences and promotes critical thinking by allowing students to make decisions and learn from mistakes. The research will also produce a broadly useful and powerful community research tool that will facilitate the research efforts of over a hundred other laboratories. The project will provide multi-disciplinary training for graduate and undergraduate students.

The premise of this research is that the bacterial nucleoid encodes a largely overlooked reservoir of topological information, and the aim is to elucidate the mechanisms by which the nucleoid functions as a primary positional determinant in the 3D landscape of a bacterial cell. Biochemical, structural, genetic, and cell biological approaches will be employed to elucidate the role of the nucleoid in the regulation cell division. In addition, a systematized approach to gene function discovery will be undertaken to identify and characterize novel factors that interact with the nucleoid and the cell envelope to drive subcellular organization. The gene discovery pipeline developed for this study will be broadly applicable to other organisms and the ordered gene expression library will be made publicly available to accelerate gene function discovery and characterization efforts in other laboratories.

POR.DRECONTENT:
Intellectual Merit: 

The research period was productive, achieving all of the program objectives. More specifically, we elucidated molecular mechanisms for proteins previously implicated in regulation of DNA replication and cell division during spore formation in the model organism Bacillus subtilis, resulting in three publications. The major impact of this work was identifying the first example of a DNA-binding protein that uses positional information encoded in the chromosome to tune the site of cell division during bacterial development (sporulation). We also developed a protocol for high throughput mutagenesis of individual chromosomal loci. We generated a community tool, the Bacillus Ectopic Inducible Gene Expression Library (BEIGEL), a collection of approximately 800 strains, each of which has an uncharacterized gene under the control of an inducible promoter. Screening the misexpression library led to the development of a broadly applicable gene function characterization pipeline. We identified two proteins, YodL and YisK, that perturb cytoskeletal function (MreB and Mbl, respectively), also resulting in a publication. Several exciting new studies were seeded from following the misexpression library screen, including discovery of a new enzyme involved in general starvation response, and identification of the first 2-acetolactate transporter

Broader Impact: 

The research efforts provided excellent training opportunities for eight undergraduate students and seven graduate students in research and scientific communication, contributing to 1) an NSF-sponsored summer research experience opportunity 2) five successfully defended PhD dissertations 3) four peer-reviewed publications (two with undergraduate authors), 4) six invited oral presentations (four by trainees) and 15 poster presentations (14 by trainees, including two undergraduates) at international conferences. Three of the undergraduate students participating in research were underrepresented minorities, three of the graduate students were first generation college degree recipients, and all five graduate students were first-generation PhD trainees. Five of the eight undergraduate trainees entered science-related PhD, MD, or MD/PhD programs and the remaining three are employed in fields related to biology, including science teaching. In addition to training, the research program led to the development of broadly useful community research tools (both methods and a gene expression library), that can be utilized to potentiate further research relevant to NSF’s mission and beyond.
